options.content:
# Analytics Component

The Analytics Component is responsible for executing scalable, batch-based data analysis. Using AI-driven policies, it derives actionable insights from alerts and events. These insights include: probable cause determination, temporal correlation between events, seasonality patterns in metrics, anomaly detection in both logs and metrics, and event clustering to identify related incidents. These capabilities enable proactive problem identification and faster incident resolution through automated root cause analysis.

The component can be broken down further into the following sub-components:

- ***Alert Classifier***: Performs classification of alerts based on their summaries to support downstream automation and decision-making processes.
- ***Trainer Service***: Handles the scheduling and orchestration of training jobs, ensuring that analytics models are trained efficiently and consistently.
- ***Spark***: Spark is the compute engine that powers all training jobs within the analytics framework. It enables distributed processing of large-scale data and supports various analytics workloads, including:
  - Spark Application: A Spark application represents a complete execution of a user-defined analytics job. It includes a driver process and multiple executor processes distributed across the cluster. Each training job—such as temporal correlation, metric anomaly detection, or seasonality analysis—is submitted as a Spark application.
  - Spark Driver: The driver is the central coordinator of a Spark application. It is responsible for:
    - Scheduling and distributing tasks across the cluster
    - Monitoring execution and handling failures
    - The driver acts as the "brain" of the application. If the driver process fails, the entire training job fails, and the Spark job cannot be scheduled or monitored.


- ***Event Classifier***: Identifies the most important event from a stream of system events. It performs the following functions:
  - Extracts paths, topological relationships, and event classifications from incoming event data
  - Computes a criticality score to rank and identify the most significant event within a causal chain or fault domain

Dependencies:
- ***Cassandra***: Cassandra is used as the historical archive for alert data, stored in the aiops.alerts table. It supports efficient long-term storage and retrieval of alerts for training, analysis, and policy generation.

panels.description: This panel monitors the status of pods in the Analytics Component of AIOps, Pods stuck in "Pending" or "Unknown" states for prolonged periods of time are problematic and may result in loss of functionality to the component.
panels.title: Analytics Component Pods

panels.description: Pod Uptimes for analytics component pods
panels.title: Analytics Component Pods Uptime

options.content:
#### Training Job: 
- Each training job—such as temporal correlation, metric anomaly detection, or seasonality analysis—is submitted as a Spark application.
- A Spark application represents a complete execution of a user-defined analytics training job. It includes a driver process and multiple executor processes distributed across the Spark cluster. 
- Failed jobs can be restarted manually but can also be restarted automatically if a schedule is configured. 
#### Spark Driver: 
The driver is the central coordinator of a Spark application. It is responsible for:
- Scheduling and distributing tasks across the cluster
- Monitoring execution and handling failures
- The driver acts as the "brain" of the application. If the driver process fails, the entire job fails.

panels.description: This panel shows the status of the Spark cluster used for analytics processing. The metric reports a healthy status when the Spark master node is responsive and at least one worker node is active. If this metric shows unhealthy status, check the Spark cluster health, as this may impact training and analytics capabilities within the AIOps platform.

0.text: Not Healthy

panels.title: Spark Cluster Status

panels.description: This panel displays the total number of currently active Spark worker nodes in the AIOps platform. More alive worker nodes mean a stronger cluster for handling larger jobs. Fewer nodes may indicate resource issues or cluster problems, risking delays or failures.
panels.title: Number of Alive Spark Worker Nodes

panels.description: This panel tracks the count of Spark driver submissions, representing the total number of analytics training jobs initiated in the system within the selected time range. Each count increment indicates a new training job has started, regardless of the specific application type.

0.text: No new spark driver submissions within time range

panels.title: Number of Training Jobs Started

panels.description: This panel shows the number of analytics training jobs that have successfully completed during the selected time period. Each increment represents a Spark driver that has finished its execution with a "FINISHED" status, indicating the associated training job completed successfully. Comparing this metric with the total driver submissions helps identify potential issues with training job completion rates and overall analytics system health. Consistently low or dropping numbers may signal job failures, scheduling inefficiencies, or resource issues.

0.text: No spark drivers completed executions within time range

panels.title: Number of Training Jobs Completed

panels.description: Count of Spark drivers that failed during execution. A low count is expected. High or increasing counts may indicate job failures, scheduling inefficiencies, or resource issues within the Spark cluster. Failed drivers result in incomplete analytics training, which can lead to outdated or missing models for various analytics services. If this metric shows persistent failures, check Spark worker logs, verify memory/CPU allocations, and ensure data sources are accessible.

0.text: All spark drivers healthy within time range
All spark job submissions healthy within time range
Spark status check reporting healthy within time range
All Spark drivers healthy within time range
All successful spark submissions within time range

panels.title: Number of Failed Spark Drivers

panels.description: Job submissions failed due to insufficient cluster CPU/memory resources. A low count is expected. High or increasing counts may indicate resource issues, poor workload distribution, or cluster scaling limitations.

0.text: All spark drivers healthy within time range
All spark job submissions healthy within time range
Spark status check reporting healthy within time range
All Spark drivers healthy within time range
All successful spark submissions within time range

panels.title: Number of Spark Training Failures (Resource Requirements)

panels.description: Count of manually shut down Spark drivers. A low count is expected, but higher counts may occur during maintenance or when training jobs are intentionally canceled. Frequent unexpected driver kills can interrupt training jobs and prevent model updates. If high counts occur outside maintenance windows, investigate resource constraints or system instability.

0.text: All spark drivers healthy within time range
All spark job submissions healthy within time range
Spark status check reporting healthy within time range
All Spark drivers healthy within time range
All successful spark submissions within time range

panels.title: Number of Spark Drivers Forcibly Killed

panels.description: Count of failed Spark job submissions. Meaning the jobs couldn't start, often due to Spark driver issues, resource exhaustion, or cluster health problems. Failed submissions prevent analytics models from being trained or updated, potentially leading to outdated anomaly detection capabilities. If this count increases, check Spark cluster health, verify resource availability, and review pod logs for specific error messages.

0.text: All spark drivers healthy within time range
All spark job submissions healthy within time range
Spark status check reporting healthy within time range
All Spark drivers healthy within time range
All successful spark submissions within time range

panels.title: Number of Failed Spark Submissions

options.content:
This service is used for extraction and classification of the most important event from a stream of system events. It performs the following functions:
- Extracts paths, topological relationships, and event classifications from incoming event data.
- Computes a criticality score to rank and identify the most significant event within a causal chain or fault domain.

Cassandra serves as the storage layer for the Event Classifier service, storing trained classification models and event criticality data across multiple tenants. It enables the service to maintain historical classification patterns and provides the distributed scalability needed to handle large volumes of event data while ensuring high availability for real-time event importance scoring.

panels.description: This panel shows the total number of failed Cassandra connections and queries in the Event Classifier service of the AIOps platform that occurred within the time range. The Event Classifier relies on Cassandra for storing and retrieving event data and model information. Persistent errors can impact event classification accuracy and priority scoring; if errors are detected, check Cassandra pod status, network connectivity, and resource allocation.

0.text: No Cassandra related errors occurred within time range

panels.title: Cassandra Errors (Total)

panels.description: This panel displays the total number of failed HTTP requests in the Event Classifier service of the AIOps platform. The Event Classifier makes HTTP requests to communicate with other services or external APIs. Failures here can prevent alerts/incidents from recieving the appropriate insights such as temporal correlation or seasonality. Review the component pods for specific error messages.

0.text: No HTTP Related errors occurred within time range

panels.title: Failed HTTP Requests

panels.description: This panel displays the total number of failed Kafka connections in the Event Classifier service of the AIOps platform. The Event Classifier relies on Kafka for ingesting and processing system events. A consistently high number of failed connections might indicate network issues, misconfigurations, or problems with Kafka. Persistent errors can lead to missed critical events and incomplete event classification; if errors occur, check Kafka broker pod status, verify broker connectivity, and ensure proper topic configurations are in place.

0.text: No kafka related errors encountered within time range

panels.title: Kafka Errors

panels.description: The Event Classifier service disk usage refers to the sizing of the classifier models and logging. If usage is above healthy thresholds, determine the sizing of trained data. High usage should be monitored to ensure the Event Classifier functionality is not interrupted.
panels.title: Disk Space Usage

options.content:
- #### Metric Retrieval API: 
  - Purpose: Allows querying and retrieving metric values from the system
  - Usage: Used to access historical and current metric data for analysis and visualization

- #### Metric Types API: 
  - Purpose: Provides information about available metric types, groups, and resources
  - Usage: Used to discover what metrics are available in the system and their structure

- #### Metric Forecast API: 
  - Purpose: Generates predictive forecasts for metric values based on historical data
  - Usage: Used to predict future metric trends and potential anomalies

- #### Blocked API Service: 
  - Purpose: Manages the blocklist of resources to exclude from data collection
  - Usage: Primarily used in POC environments to reduce data volume on smaller systems

- #### Purge API: 
  - Purpose: Triggers removal of data associated with blocklisted resources
  - Usage: Cleans up data storage by removing metrics from blocklisted resources

- #### Metric Retrieval API: 
  - Purpose: Allows querying and retrieving metric values from the system
  - Usage: Used to access historical and current metric data for analysis and visualization

- #### Service Monitor API: 
  - Purpose: Internal health check mechanism for the metrics subsystem
  - Usage: Used by dependent services to verify metrics system availability

panels.description:
Tracks the p50 over time of API operations computed at 10 minute intervals. Used to monitor the performance and responsiveness of metric processing.

p50 - shows typical performance. p50 = 1 second means half of all requests occurred in 1 second or less.
panels.title: API Ingestion Latency (Median Performance - p50)

panels.description:
Tracks the p99 over time for API operations computed at 10 minute intervals. Used to monitor the performance and responsiveness of metric processing.
p99 - gives insight into slowest response times. p99 = 1 second means 99% of all requests occurred in 1 second or less.
panels.title: API Ingestion Latency (Tail Latency - p99)

panels.description:
This panel visualizes the total number of exceptions raised on requests across various APIs/services in the Analytics component over a specified time range. 
Exceptions can lead to gaps in functionality, review the component pod health as a starting point. If pod uptime and resource usage are healthy, review their logs for any visible exceptions.

0.text: No exceptions occurred during time range

panels.title: API Exceptions

panels.description: This panel visualizes the total number of API requests observed across various APIs in the AIOps platform over a specified time range. A consistently high number of API instances or operations might indicate increased workload, potential performance bottlenecks, or the need for additional resources.
panels.title: API Requests Across Services

panels.description:
Count of pods that have exceeded 80% of their CPU limits within the time range. This will result in CPU throttling and potentially temporary loss of functionality

This will only compare against the ***current*** CPU limit of each pod. If the limits were updated within the time range, the count may be inaccurate.

0.text: pod-level CPU usage is stable - all usage has stayed under 80% of current limits

1.text: 1 pod has exceeded 80% of their CPU limits - review CPU graphs for spikes

2.text: 2 pods have exceeded 80% of their CPU limits - review CPU graphs for spikes

3.text: 3 pods have exceeded 80% of their CPU limits - review CPU graphs for spikes

4.text: 4 pods have exceeded 80% of their CPU limits - review CPU graphs for spikes

result.text: 5+ pods have exceeded 80% of their CPU limits - review CPU graphs for spikes

targets.expr: sum((((max(kube_pod_container_resource_limits{pod=~"aiops-ir-analytics-.*", container!="", container!="POD", resource="cpu"}) by (pod)) * 0.8 <= max(max_over_time(node_namespace_pod_container:container_cpu_usage_seconds_total:sum_irate{pod=~"aiops-ir-analytics-.*", container!="", container!="POD"}[$__range])) by (pod)) or vector(0)) > bool 0)

panels.description:
Count of pods that have exceeded 80% of their memory limits within the time range.

This will only compare against the ***current*** memory limit of each pod. If the limits were updated within the time range, the count may be inaccurate.

0.text: pod-level memory usage is stable - all usage has stayed under 80% of current limits

1.text: 1 pod has exceeded 80% of their memory limits - review memory graphs for spikes

2.text: 2 pods have exceeded 80% of their memory limits - review memory graphs for spikes

3.text: 3 pods have exceeded 80% of their memory limits - review memory graphs for spikes

4.text: 4 pods have exceeded 80% of their memory limits - review memory graphs for spikes

result.text: 5+ pods have exceeded 80% of their memory limits - review memory graphs for spikes

targets.expr: sum((((max(kube_pod_container_resource_limits{pod=~"aiops-ir-analytics-.*", container!="", container!="POD", resource="memory"}) by (pod)) * 0.8 <= max(max_over_time(container_memory_working_set_bytes{pod=~"aiops-ir-analytics-.*", container!="", container!="POD"}[$__range])) by (pod)) or vector(0)) > bool 0)

panels.description:
Count of pods that have exceeded their CPU limits within the time range. This will result in CPU throttling and potentially temporary loss of functionality.

This will only compare against the ***current*** CPU limit of each pod. If the limits were updated within the time range, the count may be inaccurate.

0.text: all pod-level CPU usage has stayed under current limits

1.text: 1 pod has exceeded their CPU limits - review CPU graphs for spikes

2.text: 2 pods have exceeded their CPU limits - review CPU graphs for spikes

3.text: 3 pods have exceeded their CPU limits - review CPU graphs for spikes

panels.description:
Count of component pods that have exceeded their memory limits within the time range.

This will only compare against the ***current*** memory limit of each pod. If the limits were updated within the time range, the count may be inaccurate.

0.text: all pod-level memory usage has stayed under current limits

1.text: 1 pod has exceeded their memory limits - review memory graphs for spikes

2.text: 2 pods have exceeded their memory limits - review memory graphs for spikes

3.text: 3 pods have exceeded their memory limits - review memory graphs for spikes

panels.description: This panel displays the per-second CPU usage rate of Spark Master pod in the Analytics component. High CPU usage may indicate that the Spark Master pod are under heavy load, potentially impacting analytics execution performance. Monitor this metric to ensure optimal resource allocation and efficient processing of analytics tasks.
panels.title: Spark Master Node CPU Usage

panels.description: This panel displays the working set memory usage of Spark Master Node pods in the Analytics component. High memory usage may indicate that the Spark Master Node  are consuming significant resources, potentially impacting policy execution performance. Monitor this metric to ensure optimal resource allocation and efficient processing of policy tasks.
panels.title: Spark Master Node Memory  Usage
